ja41:1.1: After an act of jealousy towards an arahant in a distant past life, so the story goes, Mittaka’s bad character, as much as his bad kamma, resulted in a series of extravagant tragedies over many lives, in which he often plays the role of a scapegoat.
ja41:1.3: Mittaka is called Mittavindaka in the past life story and Losaka Tissa in the story of the present.
ja41:1.4: The details of how he came to be hanging off a goat’s foot are absurd and too complex to relate here. But the narrative collates several stories of the archetypal scapegoat type, subsuming this ancient mythic and ritual idea under the doctrine of kamma.
